roleset.name: Typical adj, not a construction

role.descr: Stimulus, (possibly non-agentive) thing causing adj attribute to existl
Experiencer, thing that is characterized by adj attributel
Other frequent/core arguments not covered by argMs

example.name: With Stimulus
example.text: In one way , the psyllium middlemen -- the buyers and exporters -- are glad to keep news of the boom to themselves .
example.arg: the psyllium middlemen -- the buyers and exporters
to keep news of the boom to themselves
example.note: The "to" phrase indicates what causes them to be glad, it is the stimulus.

example.name: Wtih related verb -- tolerate, but good example
example.text: Former National Assemblyman Hong Sa - Duk , now a radio commentator , says the problem is intolerable for many people .
example.note: Tolerate verb has args-- arg0: tolerator, arg1: thing tolerated.

example.name: No stimulus, with arg2
example.text: Any major attempt to revamp the health - care system is likely to trigger opposition from politically powerful interest groups.
example.arg: Any major attempt to revamp the health - care system
to trigger opposition from politically powerful interest groups

example.name: With concatenation
example.text: He was wise to have stayed away ; it had been an unutterably dull evening.
example.note: The entity that is wise is "he stayed away," but the subject of this is extracted in this construction, thus requiring concatenation. Many mental ability adjectives are compatible with this.

roleset.note: Use this template if the adjective DOES NOT have an etymologically related verb (e.g. annoying --> annoy). If it does have a related verb, consult the verb roleset and follow those arguments as they are expressed by the adjective predicate.

roleset.name: Degree Construction

role.descr: degree word: too, enough, so etc.

roles.note: All other arguments stem from the adjective -- e.g. choice of arg0, arg1, presence of arg2.

role.descr: comlement: for X, to X, that X

roleset.note: These consist of a degree word and a complement (often a clause), and is compatible with any gradable adjectives.

example.name: Too X to Y
example.text: But board members say he took so long to decide how to vote that by the time he decided , it was too late to try to draw other members to his position .
example.note: This assumes a roleset for late where arg1 is thing that is late, and arg2 (not expressed here) is what someone/something is late for: He was late for the meeting. Notice the subtle distinction between arg2 and the "to" argument here: without the degree word, an infinitival phrase isn't grammatical: ??he was late to try to draw other members to his position.
example.arg: [too],[to try to draw other members to his position]

example.name: That complement
example.text: The competition is so intense that an owner’s loyalty to a dealership or a car is nearly non-existent
example.arg: [so],[that an owner’s loyalty to a dealership or a car is nearly non-existent]

example.name: Negative
example.text: Highway officials insist the ornamental railings on older bridges are n't strong enough to prevent vehicles from crashing through .
example.arg: he ornamental railings on older bridges
